items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  10.01
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services, and Mary Stone, PI External Evaluator
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Program Improvement Year 4 School Alternative Governance Plans Presentation
		 
Local Educational Agencies (LEA) who have schools in Program Improvement, Year 4 are responsible for working with the schools to develop a restructuring/alternative governance plan.  Andrew Hill and Independence High Schools are both in Year 4 and have been working with the District to analyze progress and construct a plan.
		 
Schools in Program Improvement Year 4 are required to do the following:
Create a District and School Liaison Team (DSLT).  This team leads the school through the PI Year 4 planning process and chooses a restructuring/alternative governance plan.  A DSLT was created at both sites following the State suggested composition, that is, supervisor of the principal, curriculum and instruction administrator, classroom teachers, member of the school’s advisory council, parents, and other informed individuals.  Each DSLT met twice and followed the CDE recommended protocol to select appropriate alternative governance option(s) and revise the Single Plan for Student Achievement.
Allow adequate opportunity for teachers and parents to comment before taking action. With assistance from committee members, information was shared and stakeholders had opportunities to comment on suggested plans.  Andrew Hill held town hall meetings with staff and parents to gather input, and Independence shared their progress with staff at meetings and parents during School Site Council meetings.
Choose one of the four following options as their restructuring/alternative governance structure.
               a.  Close the school and reopen it as a charter school.
               b.  Replace all or most of the school staff (which may include the principal) who are
                    relevant to the failure to make AYP.
               c.  Enter into a contract with an entity, such as a private management company with
                    a demonstrated record of effectiveness, to operate the public school.
               d.  Implement any other major restructuring of the school's governance arrangement
                    that makes fundamental reforms and leads to improved student achievement.
		 
          After completing the CDE recommended protocol, Andrew Hill and Independence selected 
          D, that is, to implement an alternative governance structure.
		 
          Andrew Hill High School plan for alternative governance structure - The main focus areas   
          of alternative governance structure are as follows:
  
                 *  Smaller Learning Communities
                 *  Whole school participation by department of Professional Development focusing
                     on engaging students
                 *  Assessing student learning
                 *  Extending learning to close the achievement gap
		 
		 
           Independence High School plan for alternative governance structure - The three main
           focus areas of their alternative governance structure are as follows:
		 
                 *  Develop and align instruction with content standards with focus on English language
                     learners and special education.
                 *  Implement common assessments and ongoing collaboration to inform staff about the
                     effectiveness of instruction.
                 *  Implement an intervention plan for students with multiple "F" grades.
          
      4. Ensure that the school’s Single Plan for Student Achievement reflects the alternative
          governance structure chosen above.
		   
          The alternative governance structure is represented in both Andrew Hill's Single Plan for
          Student Achievement and Independence's Single Plan for Student Achievement.
		 
          The DSLT will continue to meet on a regular basis at both high schools to look at student 
          achievement data and monitor the alternative governance plan.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Governance Structures at Andrew Hill and Independence High Schools.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  10.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Charter Compact Update Presentation
	 
The East Side Union High School District Charter School Collaborative Compact is a project in conjunction with the Santa Clara County Office of Education, Alum Rock, Franklin-McKinley, and San Jose Unified School districts and the charter schools authorized by those agencies. This Collaborative is a national project funded by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation with the goal of easing tension between districts and their charter schools and changing the often antagonistic relationships into collaborative ones. The Gates Foundation has funded many such compacts in major cities across the country. Each District who applies for the Gates Foundation Grant is eligible to receive $100,000 to get the compact off the ground and successful districts will then be eligible to apply for a larger grant which will fund in the million dollar range.
	 
San Jose is unique from other districts across the nation that have signed successful charter compacts in that there are many districts operating within the city rather than just one district, and those districts have unique charter schools and also share charter schools with other districts and the Santa Clara County Office of Education making the interrelationships among us complicated. It is the intent of the compacts signed by the districts, charter schools, and County Office to have some common elements that align and match creating continuity among schools.
	 
Dan Moser, Frank Biehl, Lan Nguyen, and Marisa Hanson participated in the opening discussions at the County Office and determined that it was a worthwhile project. Since then the team that composed the draft compact is, Kirsten King, Vito Chiala, Teresa Marquez, Grettel Castro-Stanley, and representatives from Latino College Prep, KIPP, Escuela Popular, and Summit Public Schools. San Jose Conservation Corp was invited to participate but has not joined the effort. 
 
The target areas of the East Side compact are aligned with the Gates Foundation Focus areas and are:
	 
	      *  Replicate high performing schools & closing low performing school - East Side will use an 
         alternative by:
            - Creating a common metric and definition for a standard performance level for schools
            - Developing a common monitoring protocol
	 
    *  Data transparency & sharing
	               - Demographics, performance, enrollment
	 
    *  Resource sharing
            - Facilities, bonds & parcel tax, special education, economies of scales, and students
	 
    *  Sharing/replicating best practices
            - Professional Development
	 
The draft compact is included as a separate document and contains specific items described in greater detail.
	 
The final compacts must be sent to the Gates Foundation by the end of August and are due to the Santa Clara County Office of Education by August 24th. Because of the tight timeline and no scheduled board meetings until August 30th, we are asking the board to submit any feedback on the compact to Dan Moser as soon as possible and that the Board authorize Dan Moser as Superintendent to approve the compact, in final form, on behalf of the Board.
	 
Fiscal Impact:
N/A
	 
Funding Source:
N/A
	 
Recommendation: 
It is recommended that the Board authorize East Side administration to continue working on the compact with East Side authorized charter schools and to authorize Dan Moser as Superintendent to approve the compact, in final form, on behalf of the board.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  10.03
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Cari Vaeth, Director of Adult Education and Career Services
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Approve Carl D. Perkins 132 Grant 2011-12 Grant Application for East Side Adult Education Program
		 
Overview:
The East Side Adult Education Program is part of a six program Career Technical Education consortium to receive Carl Perkins funding.  Under its guidelines adult education agencies who can not generate $50,000 in grant funding may apply for funding under a consortium model.  The four partners in the consortium are Metropolitan Adult Education, Campbell Union High School District, Mountain View-Los Altos Adult Education, Santa Clara Adult Education, and Sunnyvale-Cupertino Adult Education.  With the assistance of our consortium members, the East Side Adult Education has served as the lead partner in this consortium and is charged with submitting the application, monitoring the progress toward goal achievement, and evaluating the Carl Perkins plan annually.
		 
Accomplishments:
Utilizing information for Central Santa Clara County from the Employment Development Department, input from the five Adult Education Program Advisory Committees, and staff and student surveys, the CTE Consortium Advisory Committee identified two industry sectors and related career pathways addressed in this five year plan.  Perkins funds will be used to assist programs in Health and Science which will focus on Clinical Nursing, Medical Assistant, and Home Health Aide Assistant career pathways.  The second industry sector is Information Technology, which will focus on Administrative Assistant, Database Administrator, Support & Services Technician, Desktop Publishing, and Accounting career pathways.  The adult education programs in the consortium offer a thriving program for the completion of a secondary education and English language development and providing career learning opportunities in health, medicine, and information technology that have numerous entry and advancements options will complement our programs. 
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$37,910.
		 
FUNDING SOURCE
Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006, Section 132
		 
RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Carl D. Perkins 132 Grant 2011-12 Grant Application for East Side Adult Education Program.

TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students
	 
DESCRIPTION:  
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student's parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CASHEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CASHEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students' parents.
	 
The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in the Education Code 60851:
	 
Student A
Student B
Student C
Student D
Student E
Student F
	 
FISCAL IMPACT
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the recommended waivers.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  14.11
	  
				 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Kathy Lanford, Assistant Director of Facilities and Planning, and Donna Bertrand, C.P.M., Contracts Admin. Coordinator
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Approve Change Order #2 for Santa Teresa High School Title IX Modernization Project (John Plane Construction Inc.)
	 
The Board of Trustees approved Change Order #1 for this project at their meeting on May 10, 2011 which increased the purchase order by $98,064.84. At that time Administration told the Board that the final reconciliation of the PCO’s (Potential Change Orders) for the entire project would be brought back to the Board at a later date. Now that the Santa Teresa High School Title IX Modernization project is complete, Administration is providing the Board with the following reconciliation of the construction project purchase order #101424 with John Plane Construction.  Change Order #2 decreases the actual purchase order by $31,637.62 which means the final total amount went over the base bid amount by 14%.
	 
Change Order #2 is being submitted to the Board of Trustees for approval so that the purchase order can be decreased and all outstanding invoices can be paid accordingly. This is the final reconciliation as the Notice of Completion is also being presented for Board approval at this same Board meeting so that the project can be closed out.
